Evidence for antihypertensive medication use in children is limited. Higher doses do not result in greater reductions in blood pressure. Resistant hypertension occurs when blood pressure remains high despite taking multiple antihypertensive drugs with different mechanisms of action. Not taking prescribed medications as directed can cause resistant hypertension. Neurogenic hypertension, caused by chronically high activity of the autonomic nervous system, can also lead to resistant hypertension.
response: Resistant hypertension occurs when blood pressure remains high despite taking multiple antihypertensive drugs with different mechanisms of action, and it can be caused by not taking prescribed medications as directed or neurogenic hypertension.
